Research Group for Advanced Materials & Sustainable Catalysis (AMSC), State Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310032 China Transforming glycerol into value-added chemicals like acrylic acid and allyl alcohol enhances biorefinery sustainability. We report a one-pot gas-phase process using a dual-bed catalytic system: acidified montmorillonite (H-MMT, upper bed) and vanadium-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate (V-doped NH4PM, lower bed). The combination of H-MMT and primary V-doped NH4PM (NH4PMV) catalyst favoured the oxydehydration reaction and was susceptible to the selective conversion of glycerol to acrylic acid (Sel.- 63 %). On the other hand, H-MMT and secondary VOx-doped NH4PM ((VO)x-NH4PM) catalysts preferred the selective production of allyl alcohol via deoxydehydration reaction. Maximum allyl alcohol selectivity of 61 % was achieved by 1:2 wt. ratio of HMMT and (VO)0.2-NH4PM dual bed catalytic system. O2-TPD and XPS analyses revealed that V doping at the primary Keggin site of NH4PM increased surface oxygen defects and enhanced Mo6 + /Mo5+ charge transfer, promoting acrolein oxidation to acrylic acid. In contrast, secondary V-doped catalysts had fewer oxygen vacancies and were less effective for oxidation but showed high efficiency in hydrogen transfer from formic acid, methanol, or water, favoring allyl alcohol formation. Additionally, the following thermo-kinetic factors were evaluated for the best-performing catalysts, providing insights into the factors contributing to their high catalytic activity. Furthermore, incorporating 15 wt% dolomite into H-MMT reduced coke formation from 34.1 % to 2.54 % post-regeneration and extended catalyst life to 8 h of TOS while maintaining > 40 % product selectivity, offering a practical strategy for coking resistance. Graphical Abstract Keywords V-doping Keggin sites Glycerol Acrylic acid Allyl alcohol Dolomite Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid growth of the biodiesel industry has led to surplus crude glycerol production, exceeding 50 billion litres in 2021 [1]. This oversupply depresses its market value and poses environmental challenges, underscoring the need for efficient catalytic routes to convert glycerol into value-added chemicals for a sustainable biodiesel economy. Owing to its unique tri-hydroxyl structure, glycerol undergoes diverse chemical transformations, including dehydration, esterification, etherification, oxidation, acetalization, reforming, carbonylation, and hydrogenolysis, leading to more than 1500 products spanning food, pharmaceutical, polymer, and specialty chemical sectors [2]. Among these, acrylic acid (AA) and allyl alcohol (ALA) are particularly attractive as bulk chemicals produced through gas-phase oxydehydration and deoxydehydration of glycerol, respectively [3,4]. Acrylic acid serves as a key monomer in superabsorbent polymers, coatings, and adhesives, while allyl alcohol finds applications in flame retardants, plasticizers, and specialty resins. Intriguingly, both reactions typically occur under similar conditions-high temperatures above 280 °C in the presence of oxygen or air using solid acid catalysts [5–7]. However, achieving high selectivity toward AA or ALA remains challenging due to multiple competitive pathways leading to undesired byproducts such as acrolein, acetol, acetone, acetaldehyde, glycols, and propanediols [6]. Moreover, under high-temperature oxidative environments, condensation and polymerization reactions yield coke precursors, which rapidly deposit on catalyst surfaces, blocking active sites and causing severe deactivation [8,9]. Thus, designing bifunctional catalytic systems capable of maintaining long-term stability while promoting selective partial oxidation or deoxygenation of glycerol remains a key research priority. Keggin-type heteropoly compounds (HPCs) have attracted significant attention owing to their unique combination of Brønsted acidity, redox properties, and thermal stability [10–13]. Structurally, HPCs consist of a central heteroatom (e.g., P or Si) surrounded by twelve polyatoms (e.g., Mo, W, Si, etc.) in a highly symmetric Keggin anion framework. The Brønsted acidity originates from protons associated with the Keggin anions, while redox properties stem from the variable oxidation states of polyatoms, enabling acid-redox bifunctionality within a single material. The physicochemical properties of HPCs can be precisely tuned by substituting protons or polyatoms with other cations or transition metals at either the primary structure (into the Keggin framework) or secondary structure (counter-cation positions) [14–18]. For instance, Li and Zhang [19] reported that H0.5Cs2.5PW12O40 (CsPW) exhibited strong acidity but limited oxidation potential, whereas H0.5Cs2.5PMo12O40 (CsPMo) showed the opposite trend. By combining these phases in Cs(VO)0.2(PMo)x(PW)1-x solid solutions, leading to optimized surface acidity for glycerol dehydration to acrolein, and favourable oxidation potential for the partial oxidation of acrolein to AA. Further, it was also noticed that incorporation of VOx at the secondary Keggin structure improved the synergic interaction between the cations like Cs+, VO2+ and the polyions (PMo12O40 3− and PW12O40 3−), resulting in high selectivity of AA (60 %) and high stability. Similarly, Thanasilp et al. [20] demonstrated that vanadium doping at the secondary structure of SiW/HZSM-5 catalysts significantly improved AA selectivity, whereas Ce- and Co-modified analogs promoted complete oxidation, forming COx byproducts despite high glycerol conversions. These studies highlight that V-doping at the secondary Keggin structure governs the delicacy between acidity and redox functionality, which further directs the product distributions. Moreover, literature reports suggest that V incorporation at the primary Keggin structure favors selective oxidation reactions, including the oxidation of benzylic alcohol and terpene alcohols [21–23]. However, no systematic investigation has addressed the site-specific role of metal doping at both primary and secondary Keggin positions in tailoring catalytic behavior for glycerol valorization. Vogel and co-workers [24–28] further emphasized that Mo–V–W mixed oxides exhibit high AA selectivity through the formation of MoO3–Mo5O14-type crystalline phases, while V2O5-type oxides dominate total oxidation above 400 °C. Interestingly, our recent work revealed that Mo–V–O catalysts also facilitate ALA formation via glycerol deoxydehydration. The presence of MoVOx active species along with weak-strong acidity promoted the glycerol conversion towrads allyl alcohol selectivity [29,30]. Also, Fernandes et al. [31] demonstrated that combining low Brønsted acidity with redox-active V⁵⁺ centres favours partial deoxygenation, suppressing over-oxidation to COx. These findings underscore the dual reactivity of Mo–V–O systems in glycerol valorization, warranting further studies to disentangle active site contributions under controlled reaction environments. In gas-phase glycerol conversion, acid catalysts play a pivotal role in dehydration steps, while redox catalysts mediate subsequent oxidation or deoxygenation reactions. Among acid catalysts, montmorillonite (MMT), a naturally occurring layered aluminosilicate, stands out due to its low cost, high surface area, tunable acidity, and environmental benignity [32,33]. For instance, WOx/MMT catalysts achieved 90 % glycerol conversion with 82 % acrolein selectivity at 320 °C [34]. Nevertheless, like other solid acids, MMT suffers from coke deposition on strong Brønsted sites, restricting mass transfer and accelerating deactivation [35,36]. Acid treatment strategies enhance MMT surface area, porosity, and acidity, improving catalytic performance while mitigating coke formation [37–39]. Samudrala et al. [40] reported that sulfuric acid treatment improved pore structure (micropores and narrow mesopores changed to wide mesopores) and increased MMT surface area (188–206 m2/g), which eventually protected from pore blocking owing to carbon deposits, and extended the catalyst’s life. Similar enhancements were noted by Yu et al. [34] and Fu et al. [41], establishing acid-activated MMT (H-MMT) as a promising dehydration catalyst for glycerol conversion. To further suppress coke deposition, recent studies explored adding basic or redox-active oxides to acid catalysts. Ou et al. [42] showed that incorporating CaO or MgO into Ni/CeO2 catalysts reduced coking by activating CO2 and generating reactive oxygen species. However, excessive basicity favored other side product formation. In this context, dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2) offers a balanced approach, providing mild Lewis acidity without introducing strong basic sites, potentially optimizing Brønsted/Lewis ratios while limiting side reactions. Despite extensive studies on glycerol valorization, key knowledge gaps remain: (i) the site-specific influence of metal doping at primary versus secondary Keggin positions on acidity–redox synergy and product selectivity is not well understood; (ii) the dual functionality of Mo–V–O catalysts in driving both oxydehydration to AA and deoxydehydration to ALA under similar conditions lacks mechanistic clarity; and (iii) effective strategies to suppress coke deposition while preserving high activity and selectivity, particularly using low-cost supports like MMT, are still underexplored. Addressing these gaps forms the core novelty of this work. In this study, we selected V-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate as a model of Mo-V-O redox catalyst to investigate the effect of V doping at two distinct Keggin positions (primary and secondary) on their physicochemical property and catalytic performance for gas-phase valorization of glycerol to acrylic acid and allyl alcohol under air atmosphere (see Figure. S1 in supporting information). To explore the activity of these two types of catalysts, specifically in redox reaction, we embedded them individually in separate beds, each paired with an additional bed of acid catalyst positioned above (see Figure. S2 in supporting information). The loading of acid catalyst and redox catalyst in separated beds is based on our speculation that this arrangement minimizes the occurrence of unwanted reactions like oxidation of glycerol and its intermediates. Moreover, this setup allows for individual modification of the acid catalyst and redox catalyst, providing a clearer understanding of the individual as well as synergistic effects between acid–redox catalysts on product selectivity toward AA and ALA. Additionally, the role of dolomite-modified H-MMT in mitigating coke deposition was also studied. Through systematic characterization and catalytic testing, this study provides new insights into designing site-engineered heteropoly catalysts coupled with tailored acid supports for efficient and selective gas-phase glycerol valorization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Pristine sodium montmorillonite (Na-MMT) and natural dolomite (ND) were obtained from the Qing Yang Institute for Industrial Minerals (QYIM), Anhui Province, China. The required chemicals like glycerol (C3H8O3, 99 %), vanadium oxide (V2O5, ≥ 98 %) and vanadium oxytrichloride (VOCl3, 99 %) were purchased from MilliporeSigma (Previously known as Sigma-Aldrich or Merck, USA); phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (H3PMo12O40.xH2O, ACS reagent), molybdenum(VI) oxide (MoO3, ACS reagent), ammonium hydroxide (28–30 % NH3 solution, ACS reagent) and phosphoric acid (≥85 wt% of H3PO4 in H2O, ACS reagent) were procured from Aladdin® (China). All clay materials were purified through sequential steps, including centrifugation, washing, drying, and sieving into a fine powder. However, the chemicals were used directly without further purification. Deionized water was utilized for the preparation of all aqueous solutions. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of (NH4)4PMo11VO40 salt (NH4)4PMo11VO40 was prepared by synthesizing H4PMo11VO40 acid followed by precipitation to ammonium salt. Based on the reported procedure, 110 mmol of molybdenum oxide (15.8 g) and 4.9 mmol of vanadium oxide (0.9 g) were dissolved in 350 ml DI water contained in 500 ml R.B. and heated to boiling at 100 °C. Then 1.2 mmol of phosphoric acid (1.2 g) was added dropwise into the above metal oxide solution under vigorous stirring, and subsequently refluxed for 6 h. A clear orange-coloured solution was obtained after cooling to room temperature. Finally, H4PMo11VO40 acid was obtained by evaporating the water, recrystallizing, and drying at 100°C for 5 h. Next, to prepare the (NH4)4PMo11VO40 salt, a measured quantity of H4PMo11VO40 acid was dissolved in 30 ml of deionized (DI) water. A stoichiometric amount of ammonium hydroxide was then added dropwise to the solution, resulting in the formation of a yellow precipitate of (NH4)4PMo11VO40. The precipitate was subsequently heated to evaporate the remaining water and dried at 100°C for 5 h. The dried solid was ground and sieved to a particle size of 20 mesh and designated as NH4PMV. 2.2.2 Preparation of (VO)x(NH4)(3–3x)PMo12O40 salts The vanadium-substituted (secondary) ammonium phosphomolybdate salts were prepared by following the typical precipitation method. Firstly, a certain amount of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate was dissolved in 30 ml of distilled water at room temperature under vigorous stirring. Then the stoichiometric volumes of vanadium oxytrichloride and ammonium hydroxide were subsequently added to the above solution. Upon the addition of ammonium hydroxide, an orangish-yellow precipitate began to form immediately. The mixture was stirred for 30 min, aftermath the temperature was raised to 80°C to evaporate the water, resulting in a slurry. The semi-solid slurry was then placed in an air oven at 100°C for 8 h to ensure complete drying. Finally, the dried sample was pressed, crushed, and sieved to the particle size of 20 mesh for catalytic applications. The (VO)x(NH4)(3–3x)PMo12O40 salts were labelled based on the VO doping level, e.g., (VO)0.1-NH4PM, (VO)0.15-NH4PM, (VO)0.2-NH4PM, (VO)0.25-NH4PM, and (VO)0.3-NH4PM, corresponding to VO doping values of 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.25, and 0.3, respectively. 2.2.3 Acidification of MMT and dolomite incorporation in acidified-MMT The pristine montmorillonite (Na-MMT) was acid-activated via wet impregnation method using aqueous phosphoric acid (85 % aq. H3PO4) solution. To prepare 5 wt% suspension, first a stipulated amount of Na-MMT was dispersed into 1 M H3PO4 solution which was, kept in 250 ml round bottom flux equipped with a condenser. The acidification process was accomplished at 80 °C under constant stirring over 6 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the suspension was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min and subsequently washed several times with distilled water and 75 % aqueous ethanol. The collected solid was then dried at 100 °C in an air oven for 24 h and finally, ground to a fine powder through sieves 30–40 mesh. The acid-activated MMT is designated as H-MMT throughout the article. In order to study the influence of dolomite along with H-MMT on coking resistance, 5, 10, 15 and 20 wt% of dolomite was incorporated into H-MMT via simple mechanical mixing. A definite amount of dolomite was physically agitated with H-MMT in pastel-mortar using acetone as a solvent medium. After 1 h of agitation, the mixture was kept in the air oven at 80 °C for 30 min and then crushed into a fine powder (30–40 mesh). According to the weight percentage of dolomite (5, 10, 15 and 20 wt%) into H-MMT, the resultant solids were termed as 5-Dol/H-MMT, 10-Dol/H-MMT, 15-Dol/H-MMT and 20-Dol/H-MMT respectively. 2.3 Gas-phase glycerol conversion reactions Figure S2 clearly illustrates the design of the operating reactor used for gas-phase glycerol conversion reactions, along with the projection of the catalyst beds (supporting information). As shown in Figure S2, the glycerol conversion reactions were conducted in a continuous downflow fixed-bed quartz reactor (length of 52 cm) with an inner diameter of 1 cm under atmospheric pressure. At the isothermal zone of the reactor (10 cm in the middle), two catalysts were sequentially loaded in two separate beds and those were secured from each other as well as both ends by quartz wool. The upper bed contained the acid catalyst (H-MMT or y-Dol/H-MMT) for the dehydration reaction and the lower bed contained a redox catalyst (NH4PMV or (VO)x-NH4PM) for the redox reaction (oxidation or hydrogenation). Each catalyst bed was made of 0.2 g of catalyst (20–40 mesh) mixed with quartz sand (40–60 mesh) with 1:1 wt ratio. Before starting the catalytic experiment, the constructed catalyst beds were preheated at 300 °C for 1 h in an inert atmosphere (N2) with a flow rate of 21 ml.min−1; subsequently, 20 wt% aqueous glycerol solution (w/w) was fed into the vaporiser (at 180 °C) with a flow rate of 1 ml/min using a Kontron Instruments 422 HPLC syringe pump. The vaporised feed was then flown through the reactor using airflow (flow rate- 21 ml/min). The condensable organic products were collected hourly in a cold trap directly connected to the outlet of the reactor, and further analysed by GC-FID (Shimadzu GC-2014) assembled with an AT-FFAP capillary column of length 30 m (internal diameter- 0.32 mm and film thickness- 0.25 µm) and a flame ionization detector (see the full description of GC analysis and testing conditions in supporting information). However, gaseous products could not be analyzed due to the lack of equipment facilities. The gaseous products, minor liquid organic products and the carbonaceous depositions on the catalysts were collectively categorized as ‘Other’ for maintaining mass balance (details are given in supporting information). The glycerol conversion (X) and the product selectivity (S) were calculated using the following Eq. (1) & (2), respectively (1) X = Moles of glycerol reacted Moles of glycerol fed into the reactor × 100 % (2) S = Moles of glycerol converted to a specific product Moles of glycerol reacted × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure analysis by powder-XRD, ATR-FTIR and Raman spectroscopy Doping of metal cations at different positions in PMA Keggin impacts the corresponding symmetry and molecular arrangement, which can be monetarized by XRD analysis. Fig. 1A represents the powder XRD pattern of phosphomolybdic acid (PMA), ammonium phosphomolybdate (NH4PM), primary vanadium-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate (NH4PMV) and secondary vanadium species (VO) doped ammonium phosphomolybdate ((VO)x-NH4PM, x = 0.2). The most significant diffraction peaks of PMA were found to be in the region of (5−10)°, (18−40)°, and (45−65)°. The noticeable differences in the XRD pattern were observed when the protons of PMA were exchanged with ammonium ions; this corroborated well with the literature [43,44]. The characteristic peaks at 2θ (°) = 10.83, 15.21, 18.57, 21.6, 24.1, 26.59, 30.60, 36.14, 39.3 designate the respective (110), (200), (211), (220), (310), (222), (400), (322), (510) planes of Pn3m cubic lattice of ammonium phosphomolybdate hydrate, confirmed by the reference of JCPDS database (file no.- 09–0412). Fig. 1B shows that both vanadium (V) doping at the primary Keggin and VO-species doping at the secondary Keggin position in PMA, improved crystallinity, preserving the characteristic peaks found between 2θ= 5° to 40°. This implies the primary heteropolyion-Keggin structure was intact even after both kinds of aforementioned modification. In the case of NH4PMV, two new peaks at 2θ (°) = 60.35 and 66.10 appeared (pointed by * in Fig. 1B) because the replacement of Mo by V in the primary Keggin position disrupted the symmetry of the entity to a small extent, but the overall Keggin structure was unaffected. However, in the case of (VO)x-NH4PM (x = 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3), no such additional peaks were observed, suggesting no new phase was generated. Additionally, vanadium species (VO) doping at secondary Keggin sites of PMA did not affect the primary structure; only the doping amount had a little effect on crystallinity (as shown in Fig. 1C). Moreover, with increasing VO doping levels (0.1–0.3), the highest intensity peak corresponding to the (222) plane shifted toward a lower diffraction angle (Fig. 1D), confirming the effective incorporation of VO species at the secondary Keggin position in ammonium phosphomolybdate. The XRD of the montmorillonite (Na-MMT), acid-treated montmorillonite (H-MMT) and dolomite-incorporated acidified-montmorillonite (dol-HMMT) are displayed in Figure S3A (supporting information). The pristine montmorillonite showed diffraction peaks at 2θ (°) = 7.04, 19.80, 34.61, 36.02, 61.91, which correspond to the (001), (020), (110), (006) and (060) planes of montmorillonite, respectively [34,45]; whereas, some additional peaks were also observed at 2θ (°) = 22, 28.58, which can be assigned for feldspars, a non-clay impurity phase. The basal spacing (d001) value of Na-MMT and H-MMT was calculated to be 1.25 nm and 1.46 nm, respectively; such expansion of ca. 0.21 nm is consistent with the literature and could be ascribed to cationic exchange between hydrated Na+ ion and proton in MMT interlayers [39,46,47]. In dolomite-incorporated H-MMT, the diffraction peaks associated with dolomite appeared at 2θ (°) = 30.97, 41.16, 50.5 and 51.1 corresponding to the (104), (11−3), (018) and (11−6) crystalline planes, respectively, confirmed by the JCPDS file no. #79–1342. An impurity phase of aragonite (2θ = 26.3°) was present in small amounts in dolomite, confirmed by the JCPDS file no. #71–2396. The FT-IR spectra of phosphomolybdic acid, undoped and vanadium-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate salts are shown in Fig. 2. The fingerprint region present in FTIR spectra of Keggin phosphomolybdate anion is observed in 500–1200 cm−1. In the Keggin-type framework, there are four different types of oxygen atoms: the O atom common to PO4 tetrahedron and a trimetallic group is referred as Oa; the O atom connecting two trimetallic groups is referred as Ob, the O atom connecting two MoO6 octahedral inside a trimetallic group is referred as Oc and the terminal O atom is denoted as Od. The major characteristic absorption bands present in infrared spectra of PMA are shown as the reference of dashed lines at 1063, 960, 885, and 778 cm−1 corresponding to the asymmetric stretching vibration of P-Oa bond of the central PO4 tetrahedron, asymmetric vibrations of Mo-Ob-Mo and Mo-Oc-Mo, and asymmetric stretching vibration of Mo-Od, respectively [43,48]. The above-mentioned all characteristic peaks were also observed in NH4PM, NH4PMV and (VO)x-NH4PM salts, indicating that the primary Keggin structure was preserved even after proton exchange with ammonium ions and vanadium (or vanadium species) doping either at the primary or secondary positions in Keggin ion. However, minute changes can be noticed when fingerprint regions of NH4PM, NH4PMV, and (VO)0.1-NH4PM are closely compared. As seen in the blue inset in Fig. 2, the bands present in the fingerprint region of NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM are slightly shifted towards the lower wavenumber as the reference of NH4PM, suggesting both V and (VO)x doping caused weakening of Mo-O-Mo bond linkages. Furthermore, small shoulder peaks, obtained in infrared spectra of NH4PMV, can be seen at 1080 cm−1 and 996 cm−1 in P-Oa and Mo-Ob-Mo band regions, implying the replacement of one Mo atom by V led to a decrease in the symmetry of the Keggin framework and adding more absorption peaks [49–51]. When protons of PMA were replaced by ammonium ions, an obvious absorption band was obtained at 1410 cm−1 because of N-H stretching vibration [43]. In infrared spectra of (VO)x-NH4PM, no additional peak was observed, but the characteristic N-H band was shifted towards the lower frequency with incorporating more (VO)x species in heteropoly ion, as can be observed in Fig. 2: orange inset. So, corroborating XRD and FTIR results, it can be concluded that (VO)x was successfully doped at the secondary Keggin position in ammonium phosphomolybdate salt without causing any disturbance in the original Keggin framework. Figure S3B shows the FTIR spectra of Na-MMT, H-MMT, and dolomite-incorporated (5–20 wt%) HMMT catalysts (supporting information). The characteristic FTIR peaks present in pristine montmorillonite (Na-MMT) are found at 471 cm−1, 522 cm−1, 845 cm−1 917 cm−1, 1037 cm−1 and 3636 cm−1 corresponds to Si-O-Si bending vibration, Al-O-Si bending vibration, Al-Fe-OH bending vibration, Al-Al-OH bending vibration, Si-O tensile plane vibration and symmetric stretching of O-H attached to octahedral Al in MMT layers, respectively [52,53]. All the aforementioned bands can be well observed in both H-MMT and dolomite-incorporated HMMT catalysts, except Al-Al-OH bending frequency (at 917 cm−1), which could be caused by active leaching of Al from MMT layers during acid treatment. Moreover, the bands at 1636 cm−1 and 3434 cm−1 manifest O-H bending and stretching vibrations of interlayer H2O molecules, respectively, become weaker and are shifted to the lower frequency in HMMT and Dol/H-MMT because of cationic exchange of MMT interlayers [54]. In addition, the quartz impurity peak, which corresponds to Si-O symmetric stretching is obtained at 786 cm−1, becomes weaker in H-MMT and Dol/H-MMT, indicating quartz wasn’t completely removed even after acid treatment [55]. Another peak at 1490 cm−1 is observed in Na-MMT due to the presence of calcite impurity, but it has disappeared in H-MMT, implying acid treatment caused the removal of mineral impurities from montmorillonite. However, increased dolomite content in H-MMT (Dol/H-MMT) shows an intense peak at 1458 cm−1, which is obvious due to enhanced carbonate species. Raman spectroscopy was used to analyze the effect of vanadium substitution on the structure of the phosphomolybdic acid ammonium salt catalysts, and the resulting spectra are presented in Fig. 3. The Raman spectra of the standard PMA sample exhibit the characteristic bands at 997, 906, 608 and 251 cm−1 which are assigned to symmetric stretching modes of Mo-Od, Mo-Ob-Mo, Mo-Oc-Mo and Mo-Oa respectively, confirming the typical Keggin structure. When NH4 + ions substitute the exchangeable H⁺ ions from PMA, notable differences are observed in the Raman spectra of NH4PM, particularly in the regions between 200 and 400 cm−1 (e.g., a shoulder peak at 258 cm−1 and a new band at 344 cm−1) and between 800 and 1000 cm−1 (e.g., a shoulder peak at 958 cm−1). These changes are attributed to geometric modifications in the secondary Keggin structure. However, the characteristic Keggin bands remain largely the same, with only slight shifts to lower wavenumbers. This suggests that tuning the secondary structure does not significantly affect the primary Keggin structure in the phosphomolybdic acid ammonium salt. However, when one V replaced one Mo in the primary Keggin structure of ammonium phosphomolybdate (NH4PMV), the intensities of characteristic Raman bands significantly decreased due to the loss of symmetry in Keggin structure. Compared to NH4PM, no new peaks were observed, only the slight shift in the band frequencies towards the lower wavenumber region was noticed, implying effective doping of V at the primary Keggin site in phosphomolybdic acid ammonium salt. Conversely, in the case of (VO)x-NH4PM (x = 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3) synthesis, if (VO)x doping is increased, then a lower dosage of ammonium ion will be required to maintain charge balance, generating more lack of symmetry into the system. Probably, for that reason, the typical band intensities in Raman spectra of (VO)x-NH4PM samples were decreased with increasing the (VO)x doping amount at the secondary Keggin structure. Furthermore, no significant shift in characteristic peaks corresponding to the primary Keggin structure was observed, except for the shoulder peak at 958 cm−1, which was attributed to NH4 + substitution. This peak was slightly shifted to the lower frequency region with the increment in (VO)x doping amount from 0.1 to 0.3, suggesting accurate poisoning of VO species at the secondary Keggin site of ammonium phosphomolybdate. 3.2 Surface property analysis by BET-BJH In Fig. 4A, the N2-sorption of pure PMA displayed a type-IV isotherm with an abrupt increase in the low-pressure region (P/P0- 0.0–0.1) and another sudden jump to hysteresis loop at the medium-pressure region (0.4–0.5), suggesting the characteristic mesoporous structure of PMA. On the contrary, the NH4PM, (VO)0.2-NH4PM and NH4PMV exhibited typical type V isotherm, confirming the presence of mesopores within a specific pore width range [56]. Corresponding BJH pore-size distribution curves of the above-mentioned samples are represented in Fig. 4B. The average pore diameter of PMA was obtained to be 3.5 nm which increased to 30.7 nm after ammonium substitution. In addition, V-doping in the Keggin structure of NH4PM caused effective shrinkage of the average pore diameter to the range of 15–16 nm. Surface area (SBET) of PMA, NH4PM, NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM were found to be 23.05, 15.34, 2.78 and 5.99 m2/g, respectively. Both ammonium substitution and V-doping attributed to lowering surface area and pore volume, which is in good agreement with FESEM observation; on the other hand, compared to PMA, the pore diameter of V-doped NH4PM catalysts was found to be larger, therefore, the diffusion of reactants and intermediates would occur smoothly through the pores, and this would facilitate to their high catalytic activity. The N2-sorption isotherm curves of acid catalysts namely pristine MMT (Na-MMT), acid-activated MMT (H-MMT) and 15 Dol/H-MMT are represented in Fig. 5A. All of those catalysts depict characteristic type IV isotherms, suggesting the presence of mesopores on their surface. The Fig. 5B represents the BHJ pore size distribution of acid catalysts, revealing that above catalysts had wide mesopores, particularly in the range of 5–25 nm along with narrow mesopores at ⁓ 3.4–3.8 nm. Acidification of pristine MMT had a great impact on surface textural properties. As can be seen in the inset of Fig. 5B, the specific surface area (SBET) of Na-MMT (31.03 m2/g) was improved significantly after phosphoric acid treatment, and reaching upto 129.41 m2/g. However, dolomite incorporation (15 wt%) in acidified MMT reduced the SBET to 59.94 m2/g. Although this value was lower than that of H-MMT, it remained sufficiently high to ensure good catalytic activity in the glycerol dehydration reaction. 3.3 Morphology analysis by FESEM-EDAX The FESEM images of phosphomolybdic acid, unsubstituted and substituted ammonium phosphomolybdate are shown in Fig. 6. Compared to the PMA (Fig. 6A), the surface of NH4PM (Fig. 6B) isn’t found much different, however, the surface structure of V-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate catalysts is found to be completely different. FESEM image of NH4PMV and (VO)x-NH4PM catalysts (Figs. 6C and 6D) demonstrate that vanadium substitution at primary Keggin or secondary Keggin of NH4PM caused uniformed and spherical-shaped morphology, and this is also supported by the XRD data which implies that the crystallinity of catalysts was improved by the V-incorporation into NH4PM Keggin. Additionally, an interesting fact is noted in Fig. 6C that the NH4PMV particles are larger in size (av. particle size 1.15 μm) and have a dimple on their surface (clearly marked by red circles in Fig. 6C), conversely, the (VO)x-NH4PM particles are found to be smaller in size (VO0.1-NH4PM- 0.82μm, VO0.2-NH4PM- 0.85μm, VO0.3-NH4PM- 0.91μm) and have no dimple; however, the surface roughness seems to be increased with increasing VOx doping in secondary Keggin structure of ammonium phosphomolybdate. Corroborating the FESEM results with BET findings, it is evident that NH4PMV exhibits a lower surface area than VOx-NH4PM due to its larger particle size, a trend consistent with previous reports [57]. Table S1 shows the V/P atomic ratio of the following compounds such as NH4PMV, (VO)0.1-NH4PM, (VO)0.2-NH4PM and (VO)0.3-NH4PM are 1.03, 0.094, 0.205 and 0.289, respectively, which are in good agreement with the theoretical values (see supporting information). Additionally, the vanadium content in NH4PMV and (VO)x-NH4PM has been shown by elemental mapping (represented in the inset of respective FESEM images, see Figs. 6C, 6D, 6E and 6F), which depicts the incremental V content with increasing V or VOx doping in the NH4PM Keggin. Furthermore, no additional element was found in the appreciated amount, which confirmed the single-phase formation of each catalyst, and justified the outcomes of XRD and FTIR analysis. Figure S4 displays the morphology of pristine MMT, acidified MMT, and yDol/H-MMT catalysts (supporting information). The H-MMT particles were found to be less agglomerated and had rougher surfaces with some fragmented edge structures, resulting in a higher surface area and greater porosity compared to the pristine MMT. This is in good agreement with the previous report, published by our group [39]. As shown in Figure S4, with the increase of dolomite incorporation to H-MMT, particle size became larger, leading to a reduction in surface area, as can be seen in BET-BJH study (Fig. 5B). In addition, Figure S5 shows that higher dolomite content caused heterogeneity in the distribution of dolomite particles on the H-MMT surface (supporting information). 3.4 Chemical properties analysis by XPS, O2-TPD and NH3-TPD XPS analysis was conducted to examine the chemical state and surface composition of the catalyst samples. Wide XPS spectra of PMA, NH4PM, NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM are shown in Figure S5 (see supporting information). As for Mo 3d XPS spectra of PMA ( Fig. 7A), the peaks at 233.4 and 236.6 eV, corresponding to Mo 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 respectively, indicate the presence of Mo+6 [58]. In the case of NH4PM, the above peaks for Mo+6 were found a little bit at lower binding energies such as 233 eV and 236.1 eV, respectively (see Fig. 7B). Interestingly, in NH4PMV, we found the peaks at 232.5 eV and 235.6 eV correspond to Mo+6, along with two more peaks at 232 eV and 234.9 eV for Mo+5 (Fig. 7C). However, in (VO)0.2-NH4PM, peaks corresponding to Mo+6 were observed at 232.7 eV and 235.9 eV (Fig. 7D), which were at lower binding energy region compared to NH4PM. These results suggest that V-doping at primary Keggin of NH4PM caused significant charge transfer from Mo+6 to Mo+5, but doping of VO species in secondary Keggin structure was incapable of such charge transfer. This phenomenon could better impact on selective conversion of glycerol to acrylic acid and ally alcohol. Another interesting observation is that modifications at the secondary Keggin site, whether through NH4 + substitution or VOx doping, have minimal impact on the P 2p binding energy, in contrast to modifications at the primary Keggin site. As shown in Figs. 7E, 7F, and 7H, the P 2p binding energies in PMA, NH4PM, and (VO)0.2-NH4PM remain relatively consistent at approximately 131.7 eV. However, in the case of NH4PMV, the P 2p binding energy increases significantly to 134.1 eV (Fig. 7G). This result supports the selective V-doping at a distinct site in the Keggin structure and justifies the findings from the XRD and FTIR analyses. In addition, the quantitative analysis for different types of oxygen present on the surface of the prepared V-doped ammonium phosphomolybdates was also carried out using XPS analysis. Fig. 7 (I to L) represents the deconvoluted O 1 s spectra of pure PMA, NH4PM, NH4PMV and NH4(VO)0.2 PM, providing information about the quantity of different surface oxygens. As can be seen in Fig. 7I, the O 1 s spectra of pure PMA (H3PMo12O40.xH2O) can be deconvoluted into two peaks at 528.6 and 529.7 eV, assigned to lattice oxygen (OMo(VI)-O) and physisorbed hydroxyl oxygen (O-H), respectively, and this is consistent with the results of the literature [59,60]. In the case of NH4PM (see Fig. 7J), the peaks regarding lattice oxygen and chemically adsorbed hydroxyl oxygen (Ochem; -OH and H2O attached at the surface defect sites) were found at higher binding energies c.a. 530.6 eV and 531.5 eV, compared to PMA, indicating ammonium substitution decreases electronic charge density around O2-, which consequently decreases bond polarity and increases bond energy. The O 1 s XPS spectra of NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM are shown in Figs. 7K and 7L, respectively. For NH4PMV, three peaks were observed at 529.8 eV for oxygen bonded with Mo+5 (OMo +5 -O), 530.3 eV for oxygen bonded to Mo+6 (OMo +6 -O) and 532 eV for surface defect (Od) or oxygen vacancy. In contrast, (VO)0.2-NH4PM displayed only two peaks at 530.4 eV for OMo +6 -O and at 532.4 eV for Od. Comparing the O 1 s spectra of V-doped ammonium phosphomolybdates with PMA and NH4PM, it can be ascertained that vanadium doping into the NH4PM Keggin either at the primary position or at the secondary position generates surface defects. Another key observation was that the aspect ratio of oxygen vacancy in NH4PMV was 32 %, while it was found around 20.5 % in (VO)0.2-NH4PM . Therefore, it can be expected that NH4PMV could provide more oxidative sites and facilitate oxidative reactions. Furthermore, temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) was carried out to substantiate the XPS results. Fig. 8A represents the O2-TPD profiles of NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM. Both profiles exhibit small peaks between 50 to 350 °C, which can be attributed to physisorbed oxygen (Ophy). However, since the catalysts samples were thoroughly dried prior to analysis, these low-temperature peaks can be neglected. The TPD profile of NH4PMV shows an intense peak between 350 °C to 550 °C, corresponds to chemisorbed oxygen species (Ochem) in the catalyst lattice structure, containing two overlapping peaks at 491 °C and 458 °C, respectively. A sharp peak at 609.5 °C implies the presence of shallow lattice oxygen (Oshallow) in NH4PMV [60]. In contrast, those aforementioned peaks correspond to Ochem and Oshallow were appeared at higher temperatures than those of NH4PMV, positioned at 534.3 °C and 693 °C, respectively. This suggests that the oxygen species contained in NH4PMV can be readily released from the catalyst surface as compared to (VO)0.2-NH4PM, which may lead to better activity in oxidation reaction [61,62]. The desorption of reactive oxygen species over the catalyst surface mostly occurs below 600℃. According to the quantitative O2-TPD results, the total desorbed oxygen of NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM was obtained to be 885 μmol/g and 95 μmol/g, respectively. The order of Ochem in those catalysts is as follows: NH4PMV (745 μmol/g) > (VO)0.2-NH4PM (82 μmol/g). So, corroborating with the results of XPS and O2-TPD, it can be expected that vanadium doping at the primary Keggin site of ammonium phosphomolybdate leads to more surface defects, which in consequence generate more oxygen vacancies and facilitate oxidative reactions. NH3-TPD of Na-MMT, H-MMT and 15 Dol/H-MMT has been carried out to understand the effect of acidification and dolomite incorporation on the amount and strength of acidity in the montmorillonite catalysts. As can be seen in Fig. 8B, the strength of acidity can be classified into three types: weak acidity belongs to the temperature range of 50°C-200°C, medium acidity exhibited between 200°C-500°C and strong acidity found at temperature ≥ 500 °C. The order of total acid strength of the aforementioned acid catalysts is as follows: H-MMT (2.891 mmol/g) > Na-MMT (1.373 mmol/g) > 15 Dol/H-MMT (1.103 mmol/g). Fig. 8B reveals that acid activation by H3PO4 and dolomite incorporation in acidified montmorillonite extensively impact all kinds of acidities in montmorillonite. The pristine Na-MMT showed acid strengths of 0.032 (weak), 0.273 (medium), and 1.068 mmol/g (strong), while H-MMT exhibited higher values of 0.136 (weak), 1.21 (medium), and 1.545 mmol/g (strong). Therefore, it is ascertained that acid treatment by 1 M phosphoric acid can significantly enhance all types of acidity in montmorillonite. In addition, 15 wt% dolomite incorporation into H-MMT further tunes the strengths of the acid sites in the following manner: weak acidity-0.079 mmol/g, medium acidity- 0.696 mmol/g and strong acidity- 0.365 mmol/g. The comparative analysis suggests that dolomite incorporation significantly modifies the acid site distribution in H-MMT catalyst. Most notably, it converts strong acid sites into medium-strength acid sites. This transformation has been proven beneficial particularly for suppressing side reactions during the glycerol dehydration step. Previous studies by Chai et al. [63] and Jiang et al. [38] demonstrated that strong acid sites promote unwanted pathways including cyclization, condensation, and polymerization of glycerol and its intermediates - primary contributors to coke formation. By strategically reducing strong acid sites while maintaining medium-strength acidity, the 15 Dol/H-MMT catalyst could achieve improved selectivity in glycerol conversion to acrolein by minimizing these side reactions. 3.5 Catalytic performance Owing to easy abundance and affordable price, phosphomolybdic acid (PMA) among the heteropolyacids is extensively used as the acid catalyst in various glycerol value additions. However, there are very few reports available showing PMA as a redox catalyst [19,60]. In this study, vanadium-doped ammonium salts of phosphomolybdic acid were investigated as redox catalysts for the gas-phase conversion of glycerol to acrylic acid (AA) and allyl alcohol (ALY), in combination with acidified montmorillonite (H-MMT) serving as the acid catalyst in a dual-bed catalytic system. The preliminary studies were carried out at different temperatures (280–320 °C) for 5 h, using a sequential dual catalyst HMMT: NH4PM (1:1) in a single reactor. A maximum glycerol conversion of 62 % was achieved at 310°C within 2 h, yielding major products namely acrolein (35.5 % selectivity), acrylic acid (5.2 % selectivity), acetic acid (7.6 % selectivity) and allyl alcohol (15.2 % selectivity). Acetaldehyde, methanol, acetone, ethylene glycol, propanoic acid, 1,2-PDO, 1,3-PDO and formic acid were found as minor products. Coke, gaseous products, and minor by-products, collectively termed 'Others,' accounted for 21.5 % of the total selectivity. HMMT: NH4PM system appears to be catalytically active and highly selective for the conversion of glycerol to acrolein and allyl alcohol, but exhibits lower selectivity toward acrylic acid. Although extensive research has examined vanadium doping to enhance the selectivity of both acrylic acid and allyl alcohol, the specific factors distinguishing the two reactions remain unclear. Fig. 9A represents the impact of distinctive V-doping at primary and secondary Keggin of NH4PM on the selectivity of acrylic acid and allyl alcohol derived from glycerol via gas-phase reaction. These reactions were performed on sequential dual-bed system of H-MMT and NH4PMV or (VO)x-NH4PM (1:1 wt./wt.). Other reaction conditions such as temperature (310 °C), time (2 h), air flow rate (21 ml/min), glycerol concentration (20 wt% aq. Sol.), glycerol feed (0.1 ml/min) and total catalyst loading- 0.4 g were unchanged. The results reveal that small amount of (VO)x-doping at the secondary Keggin site of NH4PM is favourable for enhancing catalytic activity, especially for deoxydehydration reaction. Glycerol conversion increased from 62 % to ⁓92 % when 0.1 amount of (VO)3+ was doped into the secondary structure of NH4PM, and it further increased to > 96 % with increasing the doping amount of (VO)3+ from 0.1 to 0.3. In addition, the (VO)x doping in secondary NH4PM Keggin led to the straight drop in acrolein selectivity from 35.5 % to 8.2 %, however, the selectivity of allyl alcohol was seen to be improved up to a certain amount of (VO)x doping. The highest allyl alcohol selectivity of 52 % was achieved by (VO)0.2-NH4PM catalyst; meanwhile, the selectivity of acetic acid and acrylic acid were obtained to be 3.8 % and 4.6 %, respectively. Further, it was also noticed that, with the introduction of more (VO)3+ species (>0.2) into the secondary Keggin structure of NH4PM (particularly in case of (VO)0.25-NH4PM and (VO)0.3-NH4PM catalysts), the selectivity of minor products like formic acid, acetaldehyde and gaseous products increased, which as an evident can be seen in Fig. 9A. The selectivity of ‘Other’ compounds increased up to 47 % in the case of (VO)0.3-NH4PM. This probably happened because the introduction of VOx species in NH4PM Keggin led to higher oxidation ability of the redox catalysts, which in consequence enhanced the formation of more over-oxidised products (acids, aldehyde, COx). Furthermore, 0.2 of (VO)x-doping to the secondary structure of NH4PM Keggin was considered as the optimum doping amount to promote glycerol conversion to allyl alcohol under the aforementioned reaction conditions and (VO)0.2-NH4PM was chosen for further optimization reactions. In contrast, the V-substitution in primary Keggin position of NH4PM showed extraordinary catalytic activity (Gly Con. - 94.3 %) in glycerol conversion towards acrylic acid selectivity (63 %), while, the selectivity of corresponding acrolein, acetic acid and Others were found to be 8.7 %, 2.3 % and 26 %, respectively. So, in comparison between two doping positions in NH4PM Keggin, V-doping at the primary Keggin position indulges more oxidation properties compared to the doping at secondary Keggin sites. Specifically, (VO)0.2-NH4PM and NH4PMV emerged as the potential redox catalysts for the selective glycerol conversion yielding allyl alcohol and acrylic acid, respectively. This study demonstrates that engineering in Keggin sites of NH4PM enables altering the reaction routes for selective glycerol conversion reactions. Experiments ascertaining the impact of acid catalyst: redox catalyst ratio on two catalytic systems such as HMMT: NH4PMV and HMMT: (VO)0.2-NH4PM were performed, and outcomes are shown in Fig. 9B and C. These experiments were carried out under the following reaction conditions: temperature- 310 °C, 0.1 ml/min feed of 20 wt% glycerol, air flow rate- 20 ml/min and total catalyst loading- 0.4 g. The results were noted after 2 h of reaction. The optimum ratios of acid and redox catalysts in corresponding systems like HMMT: NH4PMV and HMMT: (VO)0.2-NH4PM were obtained to be 1:1 and 1:2, respectively. Beyond the optimum catalyst ratio, increasing the amount of redox catalyst (NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM) led to a decline in the selectivity of acrylic acid and allyl alcohol in their respective cases; in other words, the selectivity toward ‘Other’ (primarily contains COx) increased. This trend can be attributed to the excessive oxidative sites generated by the surplus redox catalyst, which promote the overoxidation of reactive species, including glycerol, intermediates (3-HPA, acetol, etc.) and products, and ultimately favour the formation of COx. For instance, Liu et al. reported a similar trend as mentioned above and suggested that the higher amount of Mo3VOx (redox cat.) contributes to more carbon monoxide formation due to deep oxidation of reacting species [64]. Furthermore, based on catalytic performances, we ascribed the advantages of using a one-pot sequential dual bed (DB) catalyst system over a mixed phase single bed (SB) catalyst system in gas-phase selective glycerol conversion. To prepare the mixed-phase SB catalyst system, the acid catalyst and the redox catalyst were taken according to their optimum weight ratio and physically mixed using a mortar pestle. For example, the mixed-phase NH4PMV/HMMT catalyst was prepared by physically mixing HMMT and NH4PMV in 1:1 wt ratio; whereas, HMMT and (VO)0.2-NH4PM were mixed in 1:2 wt ratio to prepare its corresponding mixed-phase (VO)0.2-NH4PM/HMMT catalyst. Experiments were carried out at the same reaction conditions as used for the dual bed system, i.e., temperature- 310 °C, time- 2 h, 20 wt% glycerol fed with the rate of 0.1 ml/min, air flow- 21 ml/min, catalyst loading- 0.4 g. Fig. 9D depicts the comparative catalytic performance of glycerol to acrylic acid and ally alcohol over two types of catalytic systems: (i) dual-bed configurations such as HMMT + NH4PMV and HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM, and (ii) single-bed configurations namely NH4PMV/HMMT and (VO)0.2-NH4PM/HMMT). The dual-bed (DB) system combining HMMT and NH4PMV achieved 94.3 % glycerol conversion, representing an 8.3 % increase over the single-bed (SB) system (86 %). In terms of product distribution (Table S2 in supporting information), the DB system exhibited significantly higher acrylic acid selectivity (63 % vs 25.7 %), and lower 'Others' product selectivity (26 % vs 49 %) compared to the SB system. Similarly, the HMMT and (VO)0.2-NH4PM combination exhibited the same trends as the HMMT and NH4PMV system, like better catalytic performance over the dual-bed system (higher glycerol conversion, enhanced allyl alcohol selectivity and reduced ‘Others’ byproducts selectivity) compared to the single-bed system. This enhanced performance likely occurred because in the dual catalytic system, acid and redox catalysts were physically separated, so, glycerol and the intermediate 3-HPA couldn’t get access to direct contact with the redox catalyst. Consequently, the chance of unwanted reactions like overoxidation of reactive species, and oxidation of glycerol and intermediates (primarily 3-HPA) became lower as compared to single-phase (or mixed-phase) catalytic systems. As a result, the dual catalytic system exhibits exceptional efficiency in facilitating selective glycerol conversion to either acrylic acid or allyl alcohol via gas phase dehydration-oxidation or dehydration-Hydrogen transfer, respectively in corresponding cases, ensuring optimal yields and reducing selectivity of byproducts. 3.6 Kinetic study In dual bed catalytic systems, glycerol conversion and product (acrylic acid or allyl alcohol) selectivity immensely depend upon the weight ratio of the acid and redox catalyst used to prepare the catalyst bed. For the kinetic study, the optimum weight ratio of constituent catalysts was consciously loaded in two distinct catalytic systems such as HMMT + NH4PMV- DB (HMMT: NH4PMV- 1:1) and HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB (HMMT: (VO)0.2-NH4PM- 1:2). The other reaction conditions were as follows: temperatures- 290, 295, 300, 305 and 310 °C (optimum temperature.), total catalyst loading-0.4 g, 20 wt% glycerol fed with the rate of 0.1 ml/min, air flow- 21 ml/min, time- 2 h. The product mixture was collected every 30 min intervals and analysed by GC-FID. The kinetic study was performed to know the order of the reactions and their corresponding activation energies. The first-order kinetic plots regarding glycerol conversion to acrylic acid and allyl alcohol over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB and HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalysts, respectively have been shown in Fig. 10A. The linear fits of the corresponding kinetic plots (-ln(1-xgly) vs time) have regression values in the range of 0.97 – 0.99, suggesting that the overall reaction order of glycerol conversion exhibits one over both the above-mentioned catalytic systems, which is consistent with the results reported by Thanasilp et al. [20] for the SiW/HZSM-5 catalyst. The calculated rate constants of glycerol conversion to acrylic acid and allyl alcohol were 0.025 min−1 and 0.032 min−1 over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB and HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalyst system, respectively. The activation energy can be determined by using the Arrhenius equation as follows: (3) lnk = ln A − E a RT Where k is the rate constant, A is the Arrhenius constant, R is the ideal gas constant (8.314 J/mol/K), T is the temperature in Kelvin, and Ea is the activation energy. The slope of the plot lnk vs 1/T indicates the value of Ea/R. The Arrhenius plots regarding glycerol to acrylic acid over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB catalyst and glycerol to allyl alcohol over HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB, are represented in Fig. 10B and the corresponding activation energies are calculated to be 162.63 kJ/mol and 155.1 kJ/mol, respectively. So compared to HMMT + NH4PMV- DB catalytic system, the lower activation energy of HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalytic system could be the most valid reason for better activity in respect of glycerol conversion. Additionally, some important parameters such as enthalpy of activation, entropy of activation and Gibb’s free energy of activation were evaluated for in-depth study. According to the Eyring-Polanyi equation: (4) k = k b T h × e ( − Δ G # RT ) Substituting ΔG# in above Eq. 4, [as ΔG# = ΔH# - TΔS#] (5) k = k b T h × e ( − Δ H # + T Δ S # RT ) (6) ln k T = ln k b h + Δ S # R − Δ H # RT Here, ΔH# and ΔS# are enthalpy of activation and entropy of activation, respectively. h is Planck constant (6.626 × 10−34 J.s), kb is Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10−38 J.K−1). The values of ΔH# and ΔS# can be calculated from the slope and intercept of the linear regression plot of ln(k/T) Vs 1/T (named as Eyring-Polanyi’s plot), respectively. Subsequently, Gibb’s free energy (ΔG#) is calculated by the following equation: ΔG# = ΔH# - TΔS#. Eyring-Polanyi’s plots of two corresponding catalytic systems are represented in Fig. 10C. In the case of glycerol conversion to acrylic acid over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB catalytic system, the enthalpy of activation and the entropy of activation were obtained to be 150.3 kJ/mol and 229.67 J/mol/K, respectively; while for glycerol conversion to allyl alcohol using HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalyst, ΔH# and ΔS# were 157.89 kJ/mol and 244.59 J/mol/K, respectively. In both cases, we observed ΔH# and ΔS# are positive, suggesting that the aforementioned reactions are endothermic, and during the reaction, randomness increases because of the increasing number of product molecules. Furthermore, Gibb’s free energies were calculated to be 16.4 kJ/mol and 15.29 kJ/mol for glycerol conversion over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB and HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalytic system, respectively. The positive values of Gibb’s free energy imply that both reactions (glycerol dehydration-oxidation and dehydration-hydrogenation) are thermodynamically non-spontaneous. 3.7 Effect of dolomite incorporation in acid catalysts on coking reduction and catalyst regeneration According to the design of our catalytic system, the glycerol dehydration takes place at the upper bed which contains the acid catalysts i.e. H-MMT. Numerous studies in the literature indicate that Brønsted acid sites are the active centre for catalysing glycerol dehydration; however, such sites are also believed to contribute to catalyst deactivation by coking [65,66]. The process of coke formation is significantly influenced by the acidity and pore structure of the catalyst. So, in this study, we added a small amount of dolomite with H-MMT, assuming that dolomite incorporation in the acid catalyst could increase the alkalinity in the H-MMT catalyst, which in consequence might improve the catalyst's life by reducing coke formation. First, we explored the impact of the amount of dolomite addition in H-MMT catalyst for glycerol conversion to acrolein (reaction condition: temperature- 310 °C, catalyst loading- 0.2 g, carrier gas - air at 21 ml/min, and feed flow rate = 0.1 ml/min, time- 2 h). Figure S7A (supporting information) displays that the highest acrolein selectivity and around 97 % glycerol conversion were achieved by 15-Dol/H-MMT compared to other catalysts. In addition, a Time-On-Stream (TOS) study was carried out for gas-phase glycerol conversion to acrolein using Na-MMT, H-MMT and 15 Dol/H-MMT catalysts ( Fig. 11A), which demonstrated that 15 wt% dolomite addition improved acrolein selectivity and glycerol conversion up to 63 % and 88 %, respectively after 5 h of TOS. This result was far better than Na-MMT (Acr Sel.–15 % and Gly Con.- 54 % after 5 h) and H-MMT (Acr Sel.–23 % and Gly Con.- 56 % after 5 h). So, in the case of 15 Dol/H-MMT, acrolein selectivity was likely enhanced due to the transformation of strong acidic sites to moderate-strength acidic sites. This is evidenced in the NH3-TPD profile of 15-Dol/H-MMT, where the major acidic sites exhibited moderate-strength acidity. Zhou et al. previously reported a similar kind of trend for gas-phase glycerol conversion to acrolein using acid-activated sepiolite catalyst [67]. However, acrolein selectivity decreased with the 20-Dol/H-MMT catalyst. This is likely because the excess dolomite increased Lewis acidity, promoting the formation of byproducts like acetol, methanol, and other compounds. Consequently, 15-Dol/H-MMT was identified as the optimized acid catalyst and was selected for further studies. Thereafter, the optimized 15-Dol/H-MMT catalyst was integrated into two double-bed systems: one with NH4PMV for acrylic acid production (process A), and another with (VO)0.2-NH4PM for allyl alcohol (ALA) production (process B). Fig. 11B shows the time-on-stream (TOS) results for these processes, comparing the performance of these new systems to the original dolomite-free catalysts. In this study, we have observed that dolomite incorporation significantly increases the catalyst’s life for both cases. By using 15-Dol/H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB catalyst system, acrylic acid selectivity was improved upto 42 % after 5 h of TOS, which was only 14 % in the case of H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB. Also, glycerol conversion was found to decline by 83 %, 75 % and 69 % after 3, 4 and 5 h, respectively, in the former case; while, in the latter case, glycerol conversion sharply fell from 94.3 % (2 h) to 73 % (3 h), 54 % (4 h) and after 5 h of TOS, it was found to be 41 % which is much lower compared to 15-Dol/H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB catalyst system. The same trend was observed in process B i.e. glycerol conversion to allyl alcohol. 15-Dol/H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalyst system showed better sustainability, like higher allyl alcohol selectivity (37 %) and higher glycerol conversion (71 %) after 5 h of TOS. In comparison, H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalytic system exhibited poor endurance, after 5 h of TOS, acquiring only 18 % of allyl alcohol selectivity and 43 % of glycerol conversion. The addition of the optimal amount of dolomite (15 wt%) modifies the strength and distribution of surface acidity in H-MMT, as confirmed by NH₃-TPD. This property, combined with a high surface area and wide mesopores (evidenced by BET-BJH), synergistically enhances catalytic endurance. This is consistent with literature reports, which indicate that these combined properties suppress coke formation and promote the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein [68–71]. Moreover, the dolomite-modified H-MMT catalyst actively promotes the subsequent conversion of the intermediate acrolein, either through partial oxidation to acrylic acid or hydrogenation to allyl alcohol. So, considering the above facts, we can say that dolomite has good potential to reduce coking on solid catalysts and improve catalytic durability during gas-phase reactions. To acquire strong evidence supporting the potential of dolomite for coking resistance, we further analyzed the amount of coke deposition that occurred after the reaction on the catalyst surface, using thermogravimetric analysis. For clear depiction, we compared the TGA of used acid catalysts (employed in the formation of acrolein from glycerol; reaction conditions- Cat. loading- 0.2 g, 20 wt% glycerol, 21 ml/min air flow, 0.1 ml/min glycerol fed, T- 310 °C, time-5 h) such as H-MMT and different amounts of dolomite-incorporated H-MMT catalysts i.e. y-Dol/H-MMT (y = 5, 10, 15 and 20) as can be shown Fig. 11C. The weight loss of the samples occurred between 25 °C to 200 °C is considered a loss of physisorbed and chemisorbed water. Then, the major weight loss between 200 °C to 700 °C is referred to as the decomposition of carbonaceous species, including coke and carbonates of dolomite. However, the contribution of carbonates in the second mass loss can be ruled out for H-MMT. The weight loss of the fresh y-Dol/HMMT catalysts in the region 200 °C to 700 °C is attributed to the decomposition of their inherent carbonate species. So, the difference in weight loss between fresh and used catalysts particularly at 200 °C to 700 °C region indicates the coking rate (Table S3 in supporting information). The used H-MMT catalyst exhibited a significant weight loss of 38.5 %. The addition of dolomite substantially reduced this weight loss, with the 15 wt% dolomite catalyst (15-Dol/H-MMT) showing the minimum loss of 12.6 %. In contrast, the 20 wt% dolomite catalyst (20-Dol/H-MMT) showed a slightly higher weight loss of 16.4 %, which is attributed to the greater quantity of carbonate species present in the higher dolomite content. In order to further explore the coking resistance of 15-Dol/H-MMT catalyst at different reaction temperatures, it was employed for glycerol conversion to acrolein (Reaction conditions: catalyst loading- 0.2 g, 20 wt% glycerol, 21 ml/min air flow, 0.1 ml/min glycerol fed, time- 5 h) at 280, 290, 300, 310 and 320 °C reaction temperatures, and after the reaction, it was characterized by TGA. Fig. 11D shows the TGA profiles of used 15 Dol/H-MMT catalysts treated at the above-mentioned temperatures. It was observed that carbonaceous species decomposition was reduced from 22.9 % to 10 % with increasing reaction temperature from 280 °C to 320 °C. Nevertheless, 15 Dol/H-MMT is efficient in reducing coke deposition on the acid catalyst at 310 °C which is generally used for all the reactions. So, we can conclude that in the sequential dual-bed catalytic system (with acid and redox catalysts in separate beds), adding dolomite to H-MMT efficiently prolongs the overall catalyst life. The regeneration procedure consisted of two steps: (1) halting the glycerol feed while maintaining the air flow, and (2) holding the system at 310°C for one hour with an air flow rate of 21 ml/min. During the pause mode, the carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface were getting oxidised and were removed by the continuous air flow. The TGA profile of regenerated 15 Dol/HMMT catalyst revealed that this catalyst had only 2.38 % coke content after regeneration (Fig. 11D), indicating the effectiveness and easiness of the adopting regeneration process. After a 1 h pause, the glycerol fed was started and continued for 5 more hours (up to 10 h TOS). Fig. 11A shows that acrolein selectivity increased in all three acid catalysts after regeneration: from 15 % to 33 % for Na-MMT, from 23 % to 67 % for H-MMT, and from 63 % to 71 % for 15 Dol/H-MMT, between 5 h and 6 h of TOS. Then again, the catalyst activity declined due to further coke formation. After 10 h of TOS, 15 Dol/H-MMT showed the best result (Acr Sel.- 42 %, Gly Conv.- 68 %) compared to Na-MMT (Acr Sel.- 11 %, Gly Conv.- 39 %) and H-MMT (Acr Sel.- 17 %, Gly Conv.- 42 %). Following the same procedure, the double bed catalyst systems (H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB, 15-Dol/H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB, H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB and 15-Dol/H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB) were regenerated; however, after regeneration these reactions were continued for 8 h of TOS, because of sharp deterioration in catalytic activity after 7 h of TOS, as can be seen in Fig. 11B. Interesting fact is noticed that when acid catalysts (both H-MMT and 15 Dol/H-MMT) was employed singly, they showed appreciating acrolein selectivity after 8 h of TOS. However, when those acid catalysts were assembled with redox catalysts (NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM) in dual-bed catalytic systems, they weren’t competent well to perform after 7 h of TOS, (as can be seen in Fig. 11A and B). This occurred because the redox catalysts (NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM) experienced sintering, which may have led to the degradation of active sites due to prolonged exposure to the high temperature. As evidence, Figure S8 clearly shows sintered particles of the V-doped NH4PM catalyst exposed for 8 h of time-on-stream (TOS) in the gas-phase glycerol conversion reaction. Notably, regenerated dolomite added systems such as 15-Dol/H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB and 15-Dol/H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB exhibited better performances (> 50 % of Gly Conv., and >40 % of product selectivity) compared to H-MMT + NH4PMV- DB (Gly Conv.- 30 %, Acrylic acid Sel.- 14 %) and H-MMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB (Gly Conv.- 27 %, Allyl alcohol Sel.- 8 %) at 8 h of TOS. So, it can be considered that dolomite would be a cost effective and easy solution to mitigate coking problem in solid acid catalysed gas-phase glycerol conversion reactions. Table S4 provides a detailed comparison of glycerol conversion to acrylic acid and allyl alcohol over different molybdenum- and vanadium-based catalysts. The dual-bed system comprising dolomite-modified H-MMT and Mo–V–O catalysts in this study shows superior performance, ranking competitively against other complex catalyst systems. 3.8 Structure-activity relationship and mechanism By critically analyzing the outcomes of characterizations, namely XPS, O2-TPD, NH3-TPD, and catalytic activity study, we have proposed a plausible reaction mechanism for glycerol conversion to acrylic acid and/or allyl alcohol, as shown in Fig. 12. The glycerol conversion to acrylic acid over HMMT + NH4PMV- DB catalytic system follows the Mars-van Krevelen pathway, where the type of acidity and oxygen vacancy in the catalyst play the most crucial role in the acrylic acid selectivity. On the other hand, the gas phase catalytic conversion of glycerol to allyl alcohol over HMMT + (VO)0.2-NH4PM- DB catalytic system followed dehydration and H-transfer mechanism, subsequently. The dehydration of glycerol to acrolein is the common primary step for both catalytic reactions. Correlation of NH3-TPD and time-on-stream data (as shown in Fig. 11A) reveals how acid strength influences acrolein selectivity. Pristine Na-MMT, featuring only weak and strong acid sites, showed low acrolein selectivity. In contrast, H-MMT, containing all three acid site types in greater quantity, improved acrolein selectivity. Incorporating dolomite into H-MMT (particularly in 15-Dol/H-MMT) converted strong acid sites to medium-strength sites, resulting in the highest acrolein yield. This confirms that medium-strength acid sites are more favorable for acrolein formation than strong acid sites. This trend aligns with the findings of Koley et al. [60], who reported that catalysts with weak and moderate acid sites (e.g., MIL88B-600PMA) outperformed those containing strong acid sites in glycerol dehydration to acrolein. Aftermath, in next step i.e. conversion of acrolein to acrylic acid or allyl alcohol, depends on the chemical nature of the redox catalyst used in the dual-bed catalytic system. Corroborating the results of XPS and O2-TPD, it was found that NH4PMV has higher oxygen vacancy compared to (VO)0.2-NH4PM, so it can provide higher lattice oxygen during the reaction and catalyse the transformation of acrolein to acrylic acid [6]. On the other hand, (VO)0.2-NH4PM was active for acrolein conversion to allyl alcohol without using an external source of hydrogen. In the former case, V doping at the primary Keggin structure of (NH4)4PMo11VO40 possesses energy transfer from Mo+6 to Mo+5. This is synergized with oxygen vacancies and facilitates the selective conversion of CO over CC in acrolein [72]. The detailed mechanism regarding the chemo-selective oxidation of acrolein to acrylic acid can be elaborated by the Mars−van Krevelen model [73]. The oxygen vacancy generated in the NH4PMV catalyst can be readily refilled by the molecular oxygen present in the carrier gas (i.e. air) used for the reaction. This molecular oxygen then interacts with the acrolein, which is previously adsorbed on Mo+6 sites and partially oxidises the acrolein to acrylic acid. A similar kind of mechanism has been delivered by Kampe et al. [74] for the selective conversion of acrolein to acrylic acid on V-Mo-W mixed oxide catalyst. For the (VO)0.2-NH4PM catalyst, the key step is the hydrogenation of acrolein to allyl alcohol, likely via hydrogen transfer from glycerol or OH-bearing intermediates [75,76]. This project investigated the specific hydrogen donor to better elucidate the reaction mechanism. In this regard, we performed the gas-phase reaction using various reactant feeds, including aqueous solution of acrolein with and without alcohol based-compounds (found in our reaction such as methanol, 1,2 propanediol) as hydrogen donor. Formic acid (HCOOH) has been reported as a reliable H-donor for allyl alcohol formation via hydrogenation by many researchers [77], so its impact on hydrogen transfer was also explored in our study. As represented in Figure S7B, the TOS selectivity for allyl alcohol depicted different trend depending on reactant feed, indicating the influence of different donor molecules in the reaction. Pure aqueous solution of acrolein showed 29 % allyl alcohol selectivity, indicating water molecules might act as hydrogen donor in the hydrogenation of acrolein. Further, at 1 h of TOS, allyl alcohol selectivity increased from 29 % to 57 % and to 78 % with the addition of methanol and formic acid to aqueous solution of acrolein, respectively; however, 1,2 PDO addition decreased the allyl alcohol selectivity to 8 %. This suggests that both methanol and formic acid are eligible candidates as hydrogen donors but the probability of 1,2 PDO as a hydrogen donor cannot be considered in our reaction. In addition, the probable pathway of acetic acid formation is also shown in Fig. 12. The Lewis acidic sites in the acid catalyst are responsible for the dehydration of the terminal hydroxy group of glycerol, leading to the formation of acetol which subsequently go through dehydrogenation and decarbonylation at the redox sites in both NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM catalysts and form acetaldehyde as a minor product. Further, oxidation of acetaldehyde produces acetic acid [64]. Meanwhile, reduction of acetol results in another byproduct formation i.e. 1,2 propanediol at the redox site [78]. Other byproducts like methanol and ethylene glycol are produced via C-C bond cleavage of glycerol on the redox catalyst [79]. In this catalytic process, the intermediates such as 3-HPA and acetol, both are highly reactive, leading to secondary reactions such as condensation and oligomerization. These reactions can produce higher molecular weight oxygenates (coke) on the surface, potentially blocking active sites. Additionally, 3-HPA and acetol are considered primary sources of COx formation, although acrolein, other hydrocarbon intermediates, and even the final products like acrylic acid, allyl alcohol and acetic acid can also be oxidized to COx. Corma et al. demonstrated that acetol has the highest contribution to coke formation compared to reactant-fed [80]. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we demonstrated that doping vanadium (V) or vanadium species (VOx) at distinct sites (primary and secondary) of the NH4PM Keggin structure selectively directs the conversion of acrolein to either acrylic acid or allyl alcohol, which is the most crucial step in our study. When H-MMT (an acid catalyst) and primary V-doped NH4PM (i.e. NH4PMV as redox catalyst) were packed in a sequential-separated dual bed system and employed in gas-phase glycerol valorization (Conditions- Tot. Cat. loading- 0.4 g, H-MMT: NH4PMV= 1:1, 20 wt% glycerol, 21 ml/min air flow, 0.1 ml/min glycerol fed, Temp.- 310 °C, Time- 2 h), the system achieved around 63 % selectivity toward acrylic acid. In contrast, a system with H-MMT and secondary V-doped NH4PM ((VO)0.2-NH4PM) attributed 61 % allyl alcohol selectivity under almost analogous conditions (Cond.- Tot. Cat. loading- 0.4 g, H-MMT: (VO)0.2-NH4PM= 1:2, 20 wt% glycerol, 21 ml/min air flow, 0.1 ml/min glycerol fed, Temp.–310°C, Time- 2 h). Both the pathways share the same initial step i.e. acrolein formation via dehydration of glycerol at the active Bronsted-acid site of the H-MMT, while the ultimate product selectivity (acrylic acid or allyl alcohol) is determined exclusively by the chemical property of the redox catalysts (NH4PMV and (VO)0.2-NH4PM). Oxygen vacancy and energy transfer from Mo+6 to Mo+5 were found as crucial factors belonging to the redox catalysts for their divergent behaviour, as evidenced by XPS. O2-TPD analysis showed (VO)0.2 doping at the secondary Keggin site of NH4PM caused an oxygen vacancy (Ov) of 82 μmol/g. By comparison, the Ov found in NH4PMV was 745 μmol/g, almost nine times higher than (VO)0.2-NH4PM. This trend was also supported by XPS, revealing that primary V doping at Keggin can cause more oxygen vacancy rather than secondary doping. The higher Ov density in NH4PMV explains its superior oxidative capability for converting acrolein to acrylic acid. Besides, the higher valent Mo active sites in (VO)0.2-NH4PM can actively participate in H-transfer from formic acid, methanol and water to acrolein, yielding allyl alcohol. So overall, this study could pave the way for designing new Mo-V-O catalysts for selective glycerol conversion reactions. Furthermore, adding 15 wt% dolomite to H-MMT optimized its surface acidity, suppressing coking by 31.72 % and enhancing selectivity for acrylic acid and allyl alcohol to over 40 % after 5 h TOS. In summary, this work represents insights into how the same component doping at different Keggin sites in a heteropolyacid can influence the reactions, and also proves that dolomite has the potential to prevent coking and prolong the catalyst life. coredata.dc:description: Transforming glycerol into value-added chemicals like acrylic acid and allyl alcohol enhances biorefinery sustainability. We report a one-pot gas-phase process using a dual-bed catalytic system: acidified montmorillonite (H-MMT, upper bed) and vanadium-doped ammonium phosphomolybdate (V-doped NH4PM, lower bed). The combination of H-MMT and primary V-doped NH4PM (NH4PMV) catalyst favoured the oxydehydration reaction and was susceptible to the selective conversion of glycerol to acrylic acid (Sel.- 63 %). On the other hand, H-MMT and secondary VOx-doped NH4PM ((VO)x-NH4PM) catalysts preferred the selective production of allyl alcohol via deoxydehydration reaction. Maximum allyl alcohol selectivity of 61 % was achieved by 1:2 wt. ratio of HMMT and (VO)0.2-NH4PM dual bed catalytic system. O2-TPD and XPS analyses revealed that V doping at the primary Keggin site of NH4PM increased surface oxygen defects and enhanced Mo6 + /Mo5+ charge transfer, promoting acrolein oxidation to acrylic acid. In contrast, secondary V-doped catalysts had fewer oxygen vacancies and were less effective for oxidation but showed high efficiency in hydrogen transfer from formic acid, methanol, or water, favoring allyl alcohol formation. Additionally, the following thermo-kinetic factors were evaluated for the best-performing catalysts, providing insights into the factors contributing to their high catalytic activity. Furthermore, incorporating 15 wt% dolomite into H-MMT reduced coke formation from 34.1 % to 2.54 % post-regeneration and extended catalyst life to 8 h of TOS while maintaining > 40 % product selectivity, offering a practical strategy for coking resistance.
